Feature: Are there definite or specific articles?
Comment: possessive marker can have a meaning of definiteness and identifiability: "The noun marked as definite by the 3rd person suffix -ni is not a head of a possessive noun phrase. It neither has an overt (“possessive”) modifier, nor is there a possessor recoverable from the context.”
Example:
ei mo:-wo-ni kusige-ɀi e-ɀi tinda
this tree-ACC-3SG knife-INST NEG-IMP.2SG cut
‘Do not cut these trees with knives.’

Feature: Do indefinite nominals commonly have indefinite articles?
Are there prenominal articles?
Are there postnominal articles?
Comment: "The noun marked as definite by the 3rd person suffix -ni is not a head of a possessive noun phrase. It neither has an overt (“possessive”) modifier, nor is there a possessor recoverable from the context.”
Example:
ei mo:-wo-ni kusige-ɀi e-ɀi tinda
this tree-ACC-3SG knife-INST NEG-IMP.2SG cut
‘Do not cut these trees with knives.’

Feature: What is the order of numeral and noun in the NP?
Comment: "Other modifiers (numerals and some other quantifiers) may be prenominal and postnominal without being raised.”
Example:
ɀube ugda
two boat
‘two boats’

Feature: What is the order of adnominal demonstrative and noun?
Can adnominal property words occur discontinuously?
Example:
pakula ugda-na-mi imexi-we wo:-ni
Pakula boat-DEST-REF new-ACC make.PST-3SG
‘As for the boat for Pakula, he made a new one for himself.’
ŋene-mi jegdige xokto agdan-di-ni ogbie-we wa:-ni ogbie bogo-wo-ni
go-INF hero road middle-DAT-3SG moose-ACC kill.PST-3SG fat-ACC-3SG
‘The hero was walking and on half way he killed a moose, a fat moose.’

Feature: Are nominal conjunction and comitative expressed by different elements?
Detailed comment:
comitative: comitative case -ɀi, comitative postpositions meŋde ‘(together) with’ (INANIM), mule ‘with’ (ANIM), geje ‘with’ (ANIM), ɀuŋe ‘together with, both’ (INANIM)
coordination: additive focus clitic -dA, contrastive focus particle -la
Example:
bi anda mule ŋene:-mi
1SG friend with go.PST-1SG
‘I left with my friend.’
mamaka aɀiga-la digeŋ-ki-ni
old.woman girl-CONT hide-PST-3SG
‘The old woman and the girls have hidden.’

Feature: Is there an inclusive/exclusive distinction?
Example:
minti [1PL.INCL]
bu [1PL.EXCL]
-u 1PL.EXCL.POSS
-fi 1PL.INCL.POSS

Feature: Is there a gender distinction in independent 3rd person pronouns?
Is there a dual or unit augmented form (in addition to plural or augmented) for all person categories in the pronoun system?
Comment: only attested for first person ‘I with you, we, two of us’

Feature: Are there three or more distance contrasts in demonstratives?
Example:
te:ti ‘this’
ta:ti ‘that’

Feature: Do demonstratives show an elevation distinction?
Do demonstratives show a visible-nonvisible distinction?
Are there demonstrative classifiers?
Is there nonphonological allomorphy of noun number markers?
Are there several nouns (more than three) which are suppletive for number?
Is there productive overt morphological singular marking on nouns?
Is there productive morphological dual marking on nouns?
Is there productive morphological plural marking on nouns?
Comment: not obligatory, not used with inanimate objects in spoken Udihe
Detailed comment:
-ɀiga/-ɀige/-ɀigo, but it doesn’t harmonize anymore and appears only as -ɀiga in Bikin dialect
borrowing from Chinese

Feature: Is there an associative plural marker for nouns?
Example:
kanda mafa-ɀiga
Kanda old.man-ASS
‘the house people of the old man Kanda’
g’ai-ɀiga
crow-ASS
‘crow and its friends’

Feature: Is there a productive morphological pattern for deriving an action/state noun from a verb?
Comment: the suffix has abstract or resultative meaning
Example:
bude-ŋku
die-NMLZ
‘death’

Feature: Is there a productive morphological pattern for deriving an agent noun from a verb?
Detailed comment:
-ŋku: a closed class of words
-mni: not productive in Udihe, in contrast to other Tungusic languages
Example:
kaŋma-ŋku
practice.evil.magic-NMLZ
‘evil sorcerer’

Feature: Is there a productive morphological pattern for deriving an object noun from a verb?
Comment: the suffix has abstract or resultative meaning
Example:
jexe-ŋku
sing-NMLZ
‘song’

Feature: Is there a noun class/gender system where sex is a factor in class assignment?
Is there a noun class/gender system where shape is a factor in class assignment?
Is there a noun class/gender system where animacy is a factor in class assignment?
Is there a noun class/gender system where plant status is a factor in class assignment?
Are there numeral classifiers?
Are there possessive classifiers?
Is the adnominal possessive construction different for alienable and inalienable nouns?
Example:
bi dil-i:
[1SG head-1SG]
‘my head’
bi nakta dil-i-ŋi: 
[1SG boar head-1SG-ALIEN]
‘my boar head’

Feature: What is the pragmatically unmarked order of adnominal possessor noun and possessed noun?
Do core adjectives (defined semantically as property concepts such as value, shape, age, dimension) act like verbs in predicative position?
Example:
uti mo: gugda
[this tree high]
‘This tree is high.’
bugdi: kägda:-ni
leg.1SG cold.PST-3SG
‘My legs are cold.’

Feature: Do core adjectives (defined semantically as property concepts; value, shape, age, dimension) used attributively require the same morphological treatment as verbs?
Comment: adjectives agree in number and case with the noun they modify
Example:
natka-wə asi bogo-wə wa-a-mi
[wild.boar-ACC very fat-ACC kill-PST1-1SG]
‘I killed a very fat wild boar.’
ei ic’a suese
this small axe
‘this small axe’

Feature: Are there morphological cases for non-pronominal core arguments (i.e. S/A/P)?
Example:
anana imaŋku-we egdi-me ima-si-e-ni
[long.ago tale-ACC many-ACC tell-IPFV-PST-3SG]
‘Earlier they told a lot of tales.’

Feature: Are there morphological cases for pronominal core arguments (i.e. S/A/P)?
Are there morphological cases for oblique non-pronominal NPs (i.e. not S/A/P)?
Are there morphological cases for oblique independent personal pronouns (i.e. not S/A/P)?
Are there prepositions?
Are there postpositions?
Do verbs have prefixes/proclitics, other than those that ONLY mark A, S or O (do include portmanteau: A & S + TAM)?
Do verbs have suffixes/enclitics, other than those that ONLY mark A, S or O (do include portmanteau: A & S + TAM)?
Comment: “all morphemes follow the root”

Feature: Is there productive infixation in verbs?
Is there overt morphological marking of present tense on verbs?
Comment: personal endings are attached directly to the stem

Feature: Is there overt morphological marking on the verb dedicated to past tense?
Comment: person marking is attached to past stem; past stem: lengthening of the last vowel

Feature: Is there overt morphological marking on the verb dedicated to future tense?
Is a morphological distinction between perfective and imperfective aspect available on verbs?
Comment: there is a perfect stem of the verb

Feature: Can the S argument be indexed by a suffix/enclitic on the verb in the simple main clause?
Can the S argument be indexed by a prefix/proclitic on the verb in the simple main clause?
Can the A argument be indexed by a suffix/enclitic on the verb in the simple main clause?
Can the A argument be indexed by a prefix/proclitic on the verb in the simple main clause?
Can the P argument be indexed by a suffix/enclitic on the verb in the simple main clause?
Can the P argument be indexed by a prefix/proclitic on the verb in the simple main clause?
Are variations in marking strategies of core participants based on TAM distinctions?
Are variations in marking strategies of core participants based on verb classes?
Are variations in marking strategies of core participants based on person distinctions?
Can verb stems alter according to the person of a core participant?
Is there a benefactive applicative marker on the verb (including indexing)?
Is there an instrumental applicative marker on the verb (including indexing)?
Can the recipient in a ditransitive construction be marked like the monotransitive patient?
Example:
bi sin-du xeleba-wa bu-o:-mi
1SG 2SG-DAT bread-ACC give-PST-1SG
‘I gave you (some) bread.’
nua-ti teluŋu-we alamasi-e-ti
3SG-3PL.POSS story-ACC repeat-PST-3PL
‘They repeated the story.’

Feature: Can standard negation be marked by an affix, clitic or modification of the verb?
Is there directional or locative morphological marking on verbs?
Is there verb suppletion for participant number?
Is there verb suppletion for tense or aspect?
Are there conjugation classes?
Are there verbal affixes or clitics that turn intransitive verbs into transitive ones?
Example:
su:le-wen-
be.sick-CAUS
‘make sick’

Feature: Is there a phonologically bound reflexive marker on the verb?
Is there a phonologically bound reciprocal marker on the verb?
Example:
sula-ʤi dabdu-masi-əti
[ski-INS compete-RECIP-PST1-3PL]
‘They competed in skiing.’
moso-masi-
fight-RECIP
‘fight with each other'

Feature: Do verbs classify the shape, size or consistency of absolutive arguments by means of incorporated nouns, verbal affixes or suppletive verb stems?
Is there a copula for predicate nominals?
Are there serial verb constructions?
Can mood be marked by an inflecting word ("auxiliary verb")?
Example:
wakca-ɀaŋa bi-si-ni
hunt-PTCP.FUT be-PST-3SG
‘He had to hunt.’

Feature: Can aspect be marked by an inflecting word ("auxiliary verb")?
Detailed comment: copula bi- for habitual and progressive aspect
Example:
sul’ai dian-a-ini bie uti
fox speak-0-PRP-3SG be.PRS.HAB this
‘This is the fox speaking.’
umi-mi bi-s’e
drink-INF be-PRF
‘He was drinking.’

Feature: Can tense be marked by an inflecting word ("auxiliary verb")?
Example:
ɀu-be ɀawa:-ti bi-se
two-ACC take.PST-3PL be.PST-3PL
‘They have captured both of us.’

Feature: Is verb compounding a regular process?
Are there verb-adjunct (aka light-verb) constructions?
Example:
bugdi-ne-mi b’a
leg-?-? get
‘start walking (lit. get self’s leg)’
ɀuge-we b’a
trouble-ACC get
‘have trouble’
simpi-we b’a
cough-ACC get
‘get a cough’

Feature: Is incorporation of nouns into verbs a productive intransitivizing process?
Is there an existential verb?
Detailed comment: compare existential (there is a dog outside) vs. locative predication (the dog is outside)
Example:
bu ɀugdi-du: bie keige
1PL house-DAT.1PL.EXCL be-PRS.HAB cat
‘There is a cat in our house.’
ba:-la in’ei bie
nature-LOC dog be.PRS.HAB
‘There is a dog outside.’
in’ei ba:-la bi:-ni
dog place-LOC be-3SG
‘The dog is outside.’

Feature: Are different posture verbs used obligatorily depending on an inanimate locatum's shape or position (e.g. 'to lie' vs. 'to stand')?
Example:
xeleba ɀueɀe we:-le-ni bi:-ni
bread table top-LOC-3SG be-3SG
‘The bread is on the table.’

Feature: Is there a notably small number, i.e. about 100 or less, of verb roots in the language?
What is the pragmatically unmarked order of S and V in intransitive clauses?
Example:
in’ei ŋene-ini
dog go-3SG
‘The dog is walking.’

Feature: Is a pragmatically unmarked constituent order verb-initial for transitive clauses?
Is a pragmatically unmarked constituent order verb-medial for transitive clauses?
Comment: only in the speech of younger speakers, due to the influence of Russian

Feature: Is a pragmatically unmarked constituent order verb-final for transitive clauses?
Example:
mamasa ule:-we olokto-ini
old.woman meat-ACC cook-3SG
‘The old woman is cooking meat.'

Feature: Is the order of constituents the same in main and subordinate clauses?
Do clausal objects usually occur in the same position as nominal objects?
Example:
bi muisi-mi nua-ni eme-gi-e-ni biɀr
1SG think-1SG 3SG-3SG.POSS come-REP-PST-3SG EB
‘I think that he must have come.’

Feature: Is the order of core argument (i.e. S/A/P) constituents fixed?
Can standard negation be marked clause-finally?
Can standard negation be marked clause-initially?
Is there a difference between imperative (prohibitive) and declarative negation constructions?
Example:
e-ɀi mudi
NEG-IMP.2SG mumble
‘Don’t mumble.'

Feature: Is verbal predication marked by the same negator as all of the following types of predication: locational, existential and nominal?
Detailed comment:
verbal: e-
existential, proprietive: anči
habitual, personal copula: e-
Example:
zugdi-le i:-e-ti abuga anči eniŋe anči
house-LOC enter-PST-3PL father no mother no
‘They entered the house; there is neither father nor mother (there)’.
bi abuga-i anči
1SG father-1SG no
‘I don't have a father.’
o-du sugdä: egdi e-ini bie
this-DAT much NEG-3SG be.PRS.HAB
‘There are not many fish here.’

Feature: Is there a morpho-syntactic distinction between predicates expressing controlled versus uncontrolled events or states?
Comment: there is a set of verbs (mostly expressing emotions) that require the accusative marking of the sole argument
Detailed comment: agda- ‘to be glad’, tagda- ‘to be angry’, gunǝ- ‘to speak’, ǝjǝ- ‘go down the river’, solo- ‘go up the river'
Example:
min-du xekui ede-li-ge
1SG.OBL-DAT hot be-FUT-3SG
‘I will feel hot.’

Feature: Is there a morphological passive marked on the lexical verb?
Example:
ana-u-o:-mi
push-PASS-PST-1SG
‘I was pushed.’

Feature: Is there a morphological antipassive marked on the lexical verb?
Is there a morphologically marked inverse on verbs?
Is there clause chaining?
Example:
käu gektin-ɀi buk-ki-ti
all freeze.PST.PTCP-INST die-PST-3PL
‘Everybody died from the cold.’ (Lit: ‘Everybody froze and died.’)
nua-ni soŋo:n-ɀi ŋua:-ni
3SG-3SG.POSS cry.PST.PTCP-INS.SS sleep.PST-3SG
‘After crying she fell asleep.’

Feature: Is there an overt verb marker dedicated to signalling coreference or noncoreference between the subject of one clause and an argument of an adjacent clause ("switch reference")?
Example:
bi ise:-mi iwana kuɀi-ge-si j’e-we-ke ɀawa-i-wa-ni
1SG see.PST-1SG Ivan bend.down-PRF-PRF.CONV.SS what-ACC-IND take-PRS.PTCP-ACC-3SG
‘I saw that Ivan bent down and picked something up.’
‘ai-we umi-lie jexe-ɀeŋe-ti
vodka-ACC drink-COND.CONV.SS.PL sing-FUT-3PL
‘If they drink vodka, they will sing.’

Feature: Is there a morphologically marked distinction between simultaneous and sequential clauses?
Are causatives formed by affixes or clitics on verbs?
Example:
umi-wen-
drink-CAUS
‘cause to drink’
sa-wan-
know-CAUS
‘let know’

Feature: Is there a causative construction involving an element that is unmistakably grammaticalized from a verb for 'to say'?
Are verbs reduplicated?
Are nouns reduplicated?
Are elements apart from verbs or nouns reduplicated?
Comment: ideophones are reduplicated

Feature: Is there productive morphological trial marking on nouns?
Is there productive morphological paucal marking on nouns?
Is there a logophoric pronoun?
Can an adnominal property word agree with the noun in gender/noun class?
Can an adnominal demonstrative agree with the noun in gender/noun class?
Can an article agree with the noun in gender/noun class?
Can the verb carry a marker of animacy of argument, unrelated to any gender/noun class of the argument visible in the NP domain?
Can an adnominal property word agree with the noun in number?
Detailed comment:
-ŋku PL
Girfanova: The whole NP is marked for number: either on the adjective or on the noun. If the adjective has the plural marker, the noun is in singular.
Nikolaeva: “Plural agreement within the noun phrase with the adjectival modifier is not obligatory”, examples provide no evidence of number agreement, supporting the description of Girfanova
omission of PL marker on the adjective makes these (->) examples ungrammatical
Example:
uligdig’a-ŋku moxo-ɀiga bi-si-ti
beautiful-PL cup-PL be-PST-3PL
‘There were beautiful cups.’
nua-ni ila ŋic’a-ŋku sita-na-ni
3SG-3SG.POSS three small-PL child-PL-3SG
‘his three small children’

Feature: Can an adnominal demonstrative agree with the noun in number?
Comment: nouns are only optionally marked for number

Feature: Can an article agree with the noun in number?
Is there any productive diminutive marking on the noun (exclude marking by system of nominal classification only)?
Detailed comment:
-ɀig’a
originally Tungusic, not related to the PL suffix
Example:
tukca-ɀig’a
hare-DIM
‘a little hare, a toy hare’
ɀolo-ɀig’a
stone-DIM
'a small stone, pebble(s)’

Feature: Is there any productive augmentative marking on the noun (exclude marking by system of nominal classification only)?
Is there a gender system where a noun's phonological properties are a factor in class assignment?
What is the order of adnominal property word and noun?
Possible Values: multistate 1: ANM - N; 2: N - ANM; 3: both; 0: they cannot be used attributively
Example:
ei ic’a suese
this small axe
‘this small axe’

Feature: Is there a male/female distinction in 2nd person independent pronouns?
Is there a male/female distinction in 1st person independent pronouns?
Can an adnominal numeral agree with the noun in gender/noun class?
What is the order of the adnominal collective universal quantifier ('all') and the noun?
Example:
kukpu-ni teu
bug-3SG all
‘all insects’
teu čind’a-wa
all bird-ACC
'all birds’

Feature: Do collective ('all') and distributive ('every') universal quantifiers differ in their forms or their syntactic positions?
Detailed comment:
gäŋa ‘every’, precedes the noun it modifies
teu ‘all’, can either precede or follow the noun it modifies

Feature: Can predicative possession be expressed with a transitive 'habeo' verb?
Can predicative possession be expressed with an S-like possessum and a locative-coded possessor?
Comment: temporary possession
Detailed comment:
“Occasionally, the Locative expresses a possessor in copular constructions”
+ Dative (which often has locative meaning)
Example:
sin-du bie xulaligi waptä-xi koŋz’o-i
2SG-DAT be.PRS.HAB red lid-PROP box-2SG.POSS
‘Do you have a box with a red lid?’

Feature: Can predicative possession be expressed with an S-like possessum and a dative-coded possessor?
Comment: temporary possession
Example:
min-du nakta dili-ŋi: bie
1SG.OBL-DAT boar head-ALIEN.1SG be.PRS.HAB
‘I have the head of a boar.’

Feature: Can predicative possession be expressed with an S-like possessum and a possessor that is coded like an adnominal possessor?
Comment: permanent possession
Example:
bi getu-i anči
1SG friend-REFL NEG
‘I have no relatives (friends).’
si wanimi xei-xi sugese-i bie
2SG long handle-PROP axe-2SG be.PRS.HAB
‘Do you have an axe with a long handle?’
bi ic’a neŋu-i bie
1SG small younger.sibling-1SG be.PRS.HAB
‘I have a small younger brother/sister.’

Feature: Can predicative possession be expressed with an S-like possessor and a possessum that is coded like a comitative argument?
Comment: proprietive case (although not identical with the comitative marker, but also has the meaning “with X”)
Example:
nua-ni ɀube ugda-xi bi:-ni
3SG-3SG.POSS two boat-PROP be-3SG
‘He has two boats.’

Feature: Can polar interrogation be marked by intonation only?
Example:
nuani tue eme-gi-ze
[3SG winter come-REP-SUBJ]
‘Will he come in winter?’

Feature: Can polar interrogation be indicated by a special word order?
Is there a clause-initial polar interrogative particle?
Is there a clause-final polar interrogative particle?
Is there a polar interrogative particle that most commonly occurs neither clause-initially nor clause-finally?
Is there a comparative construction that includes a form that elsewhere means 'surpass, exceed'?
Is there a comparative construction that employs a marker of the standard which elsewhere has a locational meaning?
Example:
nua-ni min-digi gugda ila santimetra-ɀi
3SG-3SG.POSS 1SG.OBL-ABL tall three centimeter-INST
‘He is three centimeters taller than me.’
nua-ni min-digi ila niŋa gugda
3SG-3SG.POSS 1SG.OBL-ABL three finger tall
‘He is three finger taller than me.’

Feature: Can comparatives be expressed using two conjoined clauses?
Is there a comparative construction with a standard marker that elsewhere has neither a locational meaning nor a 'surpass/exceed' meaning?
Is there a bound comparative degree marker on the property word in a comparative construction?
Is there a non-bound comparative degree marker modifying the property word in a comparative construction?
Can polar interrogation be marked by a question particle and verbal morphology?
Can polar interrogation be indicated by overt verbal morphology only?
Can polar interrogation be marked by tone?
Is there a phonologically or morphosyntactically definable class of ideophones that includes ideophones depicting imagery beyond sound?
Comment: mostly verbal modifiers, rarely part of a compound adjective or as a single adjective

Feature: Can polar interrogation be indicated by a V-not-V construction?
Can standard negation be marked by an inflecting word ("auxiliary verb")?
Example:
bi ei ɀugdi-du ei-mi bagdi
1SG this house-DAT NEG-1SG live
‘I don’t live in this house.’
bi ei-mi sa:
1SG NEG-1SG know
‘I don't know.’

Feature: Can standard negation be marked by a non-inflecting word ("auxiliary particle")?
Does the verb for 'give' have suppletive verb forms?
Is there an inclusory construction?
Is there a phonologically free passive marker ('particle' or 'auxiliary')?
Is there a phonologically free antipassive marker ('particle' or 'auxiliary')?
Can the agent be expressed overtly in a passive clause?
Is there a phonologically independent reflexive pronoun?
Is there a phonologically independent non-bipartite reciprocal pronoun?
Comment: they are bipartite
Example: men-e-men-e

Feature: Are there multiple past or multiple future tenses, distinguishing distance from Time of Reference?
Comment: multiple past tenses

Feature: Is there overt morphological marking on the verb dedicated to mood?
Example:
wakca-ɀa
hunt-SUBJ
‘Let him hunt.’

Feature: Are there special adnominal possessive pronouns that are not formed by an otherwise regular process?
Can augmentative meaning be expressed productively by a shift of gender/noun class?
Can diminutive meaning be expressed productively by a shift of gender/noun class?
Is singular number regularly marked in the noun phrase by a dedicated phonologically free element?
Is dual number regularly marked in the noun phrase by a dedicated phonologically free element?
Is plural number regularly marked in the noun phrase by a dedicated phonologically free element?
Detailed comment: -getu, but it applies only to animated nouns
Example:
ñ’aula getu etete-ɀeŋe-ni
youth PL work-FUT-3PL
‘The young people will work.’
ei ni: getu maŋga-ŋku
3SG.POSS person PL strong-PL
‘These people are strong.’

Feature: Is trial number regularly marked in the noun phrase by a dedicated phonologically free element?
Is paucal number regularly marked in the noun phrase by a dedicated phonologically free element?
Is there a large class of nouns whose gender/noun class is not phonologically or semantically predictable?
Is there grammatical marking of direct evidence (perceived with the senses)?
Comment: an evidential particle + a special past tense

Feature: Is there grammatical marking of indirect evidence (hearsay, inference, etc.)?
Comment: an evidential particle

Feature: Is there an interrogative verb for content interrogatives (who?, what?, etc.)?
Example:
j’e-we ja:-i
what-ACC do.what.PST-2SG?
‘What are you doing?’

Feature: Is there a count/mass distinction in interrogative quantifiers?
Comment: Not mentioned.
Example: adi ‘how many, how much’

Feature: Do (nominal) content interrogatives normally or frequently occur in situ?
Comment: content interrogatives take preverbal position

Feature: Can the relative clause follow the noun?
Example:
ni: su:le-i-we-ni-de ja-u-mi
man be.ill-PRS.PTCP-ACC-3SG-FOC medicine-CAUS-1SG
‘I cure people who are ill.’

Feature: Can the relative clause precede the noun?
Example:
ei kusige-we min-du suŋgele: ni: ŋene:-ni
this knife-ACC 1SG-DAT give.PST.PTCP man leave.PST-3SG
‘The man who gave me this knife left.’

Feature: Are there internally-headed relative clauses?
Example:
bi od’o-i ɀugdi-we wo:n-d-ni bi bagdi-mi
1SG grandfather-1SG house-ACC make.PST.PTCP-DAT-3SG.POSS 1SG live-1SG
‘I live in the house which my grandfather built.’

Feature: Are there correlative relative clauses?
Are there adjoined relative clauses?
Is there a decimal numeral system?
Is there synchronic evidence for any element of a quinary numeral system?
Is there synchronic evidence for any element of a vigesimal numeral system?
Is there a body-part tallying system?
Are all person categories neutralized in some voice, tense, aspect, mood and/or negation?
Is there a class of patient-labile verbs?
Comment: probably not, there is productive decausative derivation

Feature: Does the verb for 'see' have suppletive verb forms?
Does the verb for 'come' have suppletive verb forms?
Is there any accusative alignment of flagging?
Is there any ergative alignment of flagging?
Comment: there are exceptions to the accusative alignment of flagging: “the single argument of certain constructions denoting state may be encoded by the accusative noun phrase”
Example:
Weige-we aunda-ktu
floor-ACC dry.up-RES 
'The floor is dried up.' 
Si kusige-we-i 
you knife-ACC-2SG
'Your knife is sharpened.'

Feature: Is there any neutral alignment of flagging?
Comment: the accusative marker is often omitted
Example:
ŋene-mi ogbö wa:-ni
[go-INF elk kill.PST-3SG]
‘On the way, he killed an elk.’

Feature: Is there a politeness distinction in 2nd person forms?
Is there a preposed complementizer in complements of verbs of thinking and/or knowing?
Example:
bi sa:-mi iwana eme-gi-e-me-ni
1SG know.PST-1SG Ivan come-REP-PST.PTCP-ACC-3SG
‘I knew that Ivan came.’

Feature: Is there a postposed complementizer in complements of verbs of thinking and/or knowing?
Can adnominal possession be marked by a prefix on the possessor?
Can adnominal possession be marked by a prefix on the possessed noun?
Can adnominal possession be marked by a suffix on the possessor?
Detailed comment: only in the predicative construction (alienable marking)

Feature: Can adnominal possession be marked by a suffix on the possessed noun?
Can mood be marked by a non-inflecting word ("auxiliary particle")?
Can aspect be marked by a non-inflecting word ("auxiliary particle")?
Can tense be marked by a non-inflecting word ("auxiliary particle")?
Can the S or A argument be omitted from a pragmatically unmarked clause when the referent is inferrable from context ("pro-drop" or "null anaphora")?
Is root structure predominantly polysyllabic?
Are complex tonal distinctions lacking?
Comment: Janhunen (1999) suggests tones emerged in Udihe, but Nikolaeva and Tolskaya (2001) are sceptical of it

Feature: Is there palatal vowel harmony?
Is there tongue root vowel harmony?

ŋənə-’ə-i
[go-PST2-1SG]

ŋim’aŋku ‘tale’

Feature: Is there an initial r-?
Are there initial consonant clusters in native words?
Is there a voicing distinction in stops?
Example:
doli ‘deep in one’s dreams’
toli ‘frog caviar’

Feature: Are borrowed verbs accommodated through a light-verb or a verbalizer?
Are property words verbally or nominally encoded?
Is there partial emphatic reduplication of nominal property words?
Are morphemes connected linearly in a way that there is a one on one relationship between a morpheme and its meaning?
Is inflectional morphology predominantly suffixing?
Detailed comment: "The only type of affixes found in Udihe are suffixes”

Feature: Is there a mi-ti opposition in 1 vs. 2 SG personal pronouns?
Is the secondary oblique stem of personal pronouns formed with a dental nasal?
Are gerunds or adverbial participles used to mark adverbial subordination?

Are specific negative verbs and negative suffixes/particles expressed by a formally identical suffix?

Example:
jaŋpa ‘shaman’s belt’
uŋta ‘boots’
aŋma ‘mouth’

Feature: Is there a reciprocal marker that is distinct from the reflexive marker?

Is there a voicing distinction in fricatives?
Comment: only in affricates

Feature: Are there two separate liquid phonemes (r/l)?
Comment: /r/ is marginal and restricted to a small set of ideophones

Feature: Is there vowel length distinction?

ARM: ŋala
"arm"
HAND: ŋala
"hand"

Feature: Are ‘moon’ and ‘month’ expressed by the same term?

getu PL/COLL: it is written separately, but it is stated that it “immediately follows the host target and cannot be separated from it under any conditions” and that it is bound
-nA-: is obligatory followed by a possessive inflection
Example:
minti sagda-nta-fi getu
1PL.INCL big-N-1PL.INCL COLL

1SG friend-PL-LAT.SG

ami-ne-me-ni
father-PL-ACC-3SG
‘his ancestors’

Feature: Is nominative case unmarked?

sugzä-da e-mu diga ule:-de e-mu diga
fish-FOC NEG-1PL.EXCL eat meat-FOC NEG-1PL.EXCL eat

Feature: Are recipient and location expressed by the same marker?
Comment: Dative case can be used for marking location.

who girl-ALIEN-3SG come.PST-3SG

Feature: Is acting agent in passive clause expressed by a dative-marked noun phrase?

mo: due-digi-ni eugi-e-mi
tree top-ABL-3SG come.down-PST-1SG

xeleba ɀueɀe we:-le-ni bi:-ni
bread table top-LOC-3SG be-3SG
‘The bread is on the table.’
